You make a valid point that due to the lack of direct evidence, there is still some uncertainty about how the gas regulation process worked in ammonites. However, there is some indirect evidence that suggests that ammonites may have had at least some control over the gas trapped in their shells.

For example, some studies have suggested that ammonites could have adjusted the position of the siphuncle within their shell to control the amount of gas in each chamber. Other studies have shown that the size and shape of the siphuncle can vary significantly between different species of ammonites, which may suggest that some species were better adapted to regulating gas than others.

Additionally, while modern-day cephalopods may not be direct descendants of ammonites, they are members of the same taxonomic class (Cephalopoda) and are therefore likely to share some similarities in behavior and physiology. Studies of modern-day cephalopods have shown that they are capable of a wide range of complex behaviors, including problem-solving, learning, and memory. While it is not necessarily accurate to directly apply these findings to ammonites, they do suggest that cephalopods (and by extension, ammonites) may have had more complex cognitive capabilities than previously thought.

Overall, the evidence supporting the idea that ammonites had some control over the gas in their shells is indirect and based on inferences made from anatomical and behavioral similarities between ammonites and modern-day cephalopods. While there is still much we do not know about ammonites, ongoing research may help to shed more light on their behavior and physiology.
